turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 326, in the Matter of Disciplinary Proceedings against Harriet Bouslog Sawyer.
Mr. Barlow, you may continue your argument.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Perhaps some of the Court may be wondering why a speech that was made in 1952 is before the Court in 1959.
I may be facetious, yet, I am sincere when I say that the reason for the long delay is the fact that the petitioner has been accorded due process all the way along the line.
In 1952, December 14, she made this talk at Honokaa on the Island of Hawaii.
The case in which she was engaged as counsel terminated sometime in June of 1953.
Subsequent to the termination of the trial, Federal Judge John Wiig, who presided at the trial, referred the behavior of the petitioner to the Bar Association.
The matter was then referred to the Ethics Committee in July of 1954.
In September of 1954, the petitioner requested a bill of particulars, which, were supplied to her.
In November of 1954, the Ethics Committee conducted a full-scale hearing.

At which time, the petitioner was represented by a very able counsel and at which time, she had the opportunity of presenting on her behalf any and all witnesses that she thought were people who could testify to what she had said at the time of the incident related to in the complaint.
The hearing consumed 468 pages and ended on December the 8th, 1954.

The Ethics Committee Report which found Mrs. Bouslog guilty of impugning the integrity of the Court, of interfering with the administration of justice, and creating disrespect for the courts on the first complaint, and on the second complaint, with conducting a studied interrogation of a sick juror immediately after the trial in violation of Canon 23, the American Bar Association Opinion 109, and the rulings in the Rakes and Millie cases.
Subsequent to that report by the Bar Association Ethics Committee, the Supreme Court issued an order to show cause.
That order was issued July 8th, 1955.
The petitioner was granted an extension of time to September of 1955, within which, to file an answer.
Instead of the return of the order to show cause, she filed a motion to dismiss the order to show cause on October 19, 1955.
More time for filing petitioner's return to the order to show cause was requested and petitioner was granted to December.
And finally, the argument was set for January of 1956.
On January 7th, 1955, petitioner filed a motion for reconsideration of the order, denying the motion to dismiss the order to show cause.
This motion was extensively argued and denied by order filed November 29, 1955.
A return to the order to show cause was finally filed by the petitioner on December 2, 1955.

Another motion for continuance by petitioner followed, and another hearing was held.On a date set for trial, which was January 9, 1956, a pretrial conference was held with counsel for the Bar Association, counsel for the Attorney General and counsel for the petitioner being present.
Two days later, another delay was occasioned by the petitioner filing a suggestion of disqualification of Associate Justices Stainback and Rice of the Supreme Court.
Extensive argument on this motion was again held by the Territorial Supreme Court.
The Territorial Supreme Court, incidentally, held that neither Justice was disqualified.
However, Justice Stainback withdrew on his own motion.
At the pretrial conference, it was determined that under Rule 19, the petitioner could avail herself of a trial de novo.

However, the petitioner, through her counsel, and counsel for the Bar Association, and the Attorney General, and the Court stipulated that instead of a trial de novo, the matter would proceed upon a record submitted before the Committee.
The opinion of the Court was filed April 6, 1956.
The Court found that the complaint was sustained by convincing proof, by credible evidence of more than a mere preponderance.
The Court found that the charges under both complaints were proven and found that the petitioner was guilty of gross misconduct on both counts.

The petitioner then appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals under Section 1293, alleging that there was a constitutional question involved and also alleging that her right to practice law had a money tag or a value attached to it that by virtue of the fact that she was suspended for one year, the matter in controversy or the value in controversy was the amount of money that she had earned in previous years.
The Bar Association took the position that this was a simple matter of discipline involving the Canons of Ethics, that there was no First Amendment constitutional question involved.
The Bar Association took the position that insofar as the license to practice law was concerned, it was priceless and you could not attach a price tag to it.
The petitioner filed her affidavit, stating that she made an excess of $5000 and the Court, on the first hearing, granted her a stay pending the determination of the case on its merits.
Two Justices Justice concurring, and Justice Lemmon wrote a dissenting opinion in which he indicated that as far as he was concerned, that it was a very simple disciplinary matter.
There was no constitutional question involved and that insofar as he was concerned, you could not attach a price tag to the practice of law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In that connection, Mr. Barlow --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes, sir?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It seems to be that petitioners -- it seems to have been and continue to be the petitioner's position throughout these proceedings that how the penalty imposed was purportedly a suspension of practice for one year, in actual practical effect, it was disbarment.
What do you have to say about the matter?
I don't want to interrupt your presentation, but I was --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- need to know.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- the only thing I can say about that Mr. Justice Stewart, is that under our rules that if you are suspended for a period in excess of six months, that you then have to take a written examination and you again have to pass a character test.
We, in the Territory of Hawaii, at the present time, have no reciprocity with any other state insofar as admission by a motion is concerned.
When I went there, 13, 14 years ago, I had to take a bar examination that lasted five days.
I had to pass a character test.
So --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And somebody suspended for more than six months has to do the same.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And presumably, I suppose that these very proceedings would make it difficult, if not impossible, to pass the character test if that were true.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I don't know why, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: To get some answer on it --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It depends on what the -- possibly, if it ever came back into the Supreme Court, it's what this Court would consider good moral character.
Maybe our Court might decide that based on these proceedings, she doesn't possess good moral character.
It may very well be that this Court on review, as they did in the Schwerin and Cunningsburgh case, stated “In our opinion, your finding is arbitrary.
You're dogmatic, and we think that this one little incident doesn't -- shouldn't deprive the present from her right to practice law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you're not here today characterizing this as one little incident, are you?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, sir.

Now, insofar as the Bar Association of the Territory of Hawaii is concerned, we consider this a very serious breach of the Canons of Ethics and that's all we do consider, as a breach of the Canons of Ethics.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Who -- who determined -- who would determine in Hawaii qualifications to be readmitted to the Bar?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Supreme Court itself, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the Supreme Court suspended this member of the Bar for a year.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I should think it would be a very hard time.

I should think any court or tribunal would have a hard time suspending misconducts or violations of the Code of Ethics of a lawyer for a year and then say that because he suspended you for a year, which means, a year thereafter, you never can be admitted again.
That they will ask -- indeed, wasn't there one member who thought she should be disbarred?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: One member of the Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The Court refused --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- felt --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to disbar her.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, they can't subsequently disbar under the pretense that they won't allow her to take the examination if she doesn't satisfy the requirement.
I should think --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It's very possible, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't know anything about it, but I should have a hard time finding that the Court was justified when it found that the appropriate punishment is a year -- to be suspended for a year then say, "Oh well, that meant -- that year meant that you'll forever have to disqualify.”

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Of course, the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That seems to me to be playing tricks for its own determination.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It may very well be, sir, but the possibility arises at something, maybe the young lady could never pass a written test again, --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's a different --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- may --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- I'm not talking about that but that's a different story.

If fair questions were put and the intellectual test isn't met, I'm merely suggesting that the Court that said a year's suspension is appropriate response to the misconduct that they've found, they couldn't, afterwards, say the year's suspension meant light suspension.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They could say it passed a very heavy burden on her, couldn't they, one that's very difficult to get over?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, they could say that “it's up to you to carry the ball,” so to speak, “to prove to us that you're a person of good moral character” but as Justice Frankfurter indicates, that they suspended her for a year.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anyhow, we took a case that didn't have -- that was, I should think, less clear than this and we thought we could review a determination.
I think your Court that solemnly said “you are to be suspended for a year” can, on the same basis, say, “All we meant was that meant life.”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That would depend on the feelings and beliefs of those who presided in the Supreme Court of Hawaii and those who passed on the case here as it came back at the time it came here, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I might say for the Court's benefit that as soon as we become a state, we'll have a new Supreme Court and the people that participated in this proceeding more likely will not be members of the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why is that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Because of age considerations.
Under our constitution, there's an age limitation and two of the Judges would be automatically disqualified because of age.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm merely suggesting that I thought we had decided the Court can't be or a state court can't be arbitrary even as to admission or continuance at the Bar, and I can't imagine anything more arbitrary than for a court, a predecessor court, if you will, who said a year would be appropriate response to wrong doings then saying a year meant life.
I can't imagine anything more arbitrary than that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do your rules require with reference to the burden that one has to meet who has been suspended for a year?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We have no rules on that sir.
The only --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No rules of any kind?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, that's right, sir.
The only rule we have is that a person who has been suspended for a period in excess of six months must satisfy the character qualifications and take a written test, --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Like any due applicant.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- the same as she was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Like anyone who has never been admitted to the Bar.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.
The same as if you were applying for admission de novo.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Take the same questions.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The same examination, sir.
It isn't a special examination.
You take the same examination that a law student takes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This suspension is not -- has not been properly set off.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It has not.
There is a stay order that was issued by the Ninth Circuit Court, so that she has been practicing and carrying on her profession since the hearings.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, what has to be the size of your new Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Five Judges, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Presently on the Bar?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Three.

When -- when we got to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, may it please the Court, we contended, initially, that the Ninth Circuit Court had no jurisdiction to accept this case under Title 28 Section 1293.
The Court ruled against us two-to-one, Justice Lennon dissenting.
Then, the matter was set down for a hearing, a full-scale hearing, before another three-man panel.
We argued the case, we argued the merits of the case before this panel, and the panel never came up with a decision.
Either by hearsay or through the grapevine, we found out that that panel did not agree with the first panel.
Insofar as jurisdiction was concerned, they felt that the Ninth Circuit Court did not have jurisdiction, so they set the matter down for a full- scale hearing before a nine-man court.
And we then argued the matter before a nine-man court.
The opinion reflects seven members four-for, and three-against.
Justice Denman, who was the Chief Justice at that time, retired after the case was argued and Justice Lemmon died, leaving seven Judges to participate.
That Court found that the Bar Association had sustained its burden.
That Court found that the petitioner was guilty of the conduct that was charged in the complaint.

That Court indicated in its decision that they thought that they held jurisdiction by the very narrowest of threads insofar as the first count of the complaint involving her claim of freedom of speech was concerned.

Insofar as count 2, involving the incident with the juror pool was concerned, they indicated that if we weren't -- if the petitioner wasn't in Court on count 1, she certainly wouldn't be in Court on count 2.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there any expressed finding that the leave had embarrassed the conduct of the trial?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Ninth Circuit Court did so find, sir, the majority opinion, that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Expressed by the rules?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- that the burden was sustained by clear and convincing evidence that she did attack the integrity of the Judge.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now, that isn't the question.
My question was the expression was or wasn't that the findings of the fact that her conduct had embarrassed the conduct of the trial.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, sir.
There was no finding that in fact, her conduct had embarrassed the Court or the trial.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So, there was a finding of guilty in that trial?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There was a finding of guilty insofar as the defendants were concerned --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- at the trial, yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The essence of the trial really is an unprofessional conduct of a lawyer throughout talking about a case while it, perhaps, progressed.
Do you say it went that far?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I would say it went that far because the majority opinion by Justice Chambers says that it is a serious violation and a breach to the Canons of Ethics for a lawyer to litigate by day and castigate by night.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Publicly.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Publicly, that's right.

And as the Court will be familiarized with the tone and tenor of her remarks, as reflected in the appendix to our brief, in that speech entitled “Fear,” which she made two days or three days, I think the indictment was returned on August 29th or 28th, 1951.
The day following that she and Mr. Symonds entered their names as attorney of record, and two days later, on Labor Day, or three days later, she made that speech that is appended to our --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How many --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- brief.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- Smith Act trials had there been in Hawaii?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: One, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: This is the only one?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: This was the only one.
That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, this Labor Day speech was made before there was any trial, a couple of days after the indictment in this case.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And how long before the trial in this case was ended?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, the trial actually started the day after election in 1952.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, this was 14 --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: So, this --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- 15 months before, right?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: This was made approximately --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: More than a year before.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- 14 months before.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: And you said, yesterday, that that speech that's relevant here is showing it, what?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: A pattern.

The reason that we introduced the pamphlet “Fear” and some of the other speeches that she had made was to show the Committee and the Court that this was not a spontaneous exclamation or a spontaneous suggestion on her part, that it was part of a program, part of a plan and design to bring discredit upon the Judges and discredit upon the courts and to show the community in which she resided that Smith Act trials were, in effect, a conspiracy.

If the Court will read very carefully the notes, Matsuoka's notes, the thoughts contained in Matsuoka's notes, the testimony of all the witnesses that testified at the hearing, I think the Court can very easily come to the conclusion that she was preaching to the community at large that the Government and the Court were conspiring.
She talked --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that a crime in Hawaii?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: During the litigation, sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'm talking about this pretrial speech.
It would -- would that be seditious libel or --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not insofar as the Fear pamphlet is concerned, sir.

But when you take that speech, you can come to the conclusion that this was not a spontaneous declaration on her part, that she knew what she was talking about, that she wasn't excited or agitated or probably, for that moment, mad about something, that this was part of a program and whether the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean that she held those dues consistently, is that what you mean?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You mean you can't be against the Smith Act and --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes.
I know that there are a lot of people against the Smith Act and I think that you can be legitimately against anything under our constitution.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Can you say it?
Can you say it if you aren't?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir?
You can say it if you -- if you aren't?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If you are, that opinion, --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: If you are, you --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- can you say --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Under the First Amendment, you can express yourself insofar as the Smith Act is concerned, but that's not our problem here.
Our problem here is that she not only held these views, but expressed them during the pendency of a case in which she was one of the very active counsels.

And if the Court will read the colloquy between Judge Wiig and a petitioner, the Court will find out that the petitioner, apparently, was a little aggravated because the Judge was allowing certain kinds of testimony into the record because when the Judge asked her, “Did you make the statement that rather, horrible and shocking things go on in this trial?”
She said, and this is only two days later, “I have no recollection of making that statement,” she says, “but I want it clearly understood.”
And I would like to invite the Court's attention to page 29 of the record.
This is Exhibit A, the colloquy between a petitioner and Judge Wiig.
“As the Court can see, my remarks were directly toward the conduct of the prosecution and were not directed toward the Court.”

And this is the part that I want to invite the Court's attention to, “By that I do not mean to say that the defense counsel, in any way, received from the position that was taken in the brief filed in connection with the Crouch's testimony in which we believe we have cited authorities showing that Your Honor has admitted evidence which is not admissible even in ordinary conspiracy cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's wrong with that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There's nothing wrong with it except that it corroborates Matsuoka's notes, it corroborates the witness' testimony that she did say that the Government and the Court were engaged in a conspiracy whereby they were widening the rules of evidence, whereby the rules of evidence were being scrapped so that the Government could make out a case.
And in one --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is the complaint that she used the word “conspiracy”?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is the complaint that she used the word “conspiracy” or is it what she said?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, the complaint is in what she said.
She did not, in so many words, or she did not use the word “conspiracy”.
She did not say that the Government conspired with --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understood you to say, several times, that she accused the Government of conspiring to do this.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, that's my own --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought you did.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's my own language.
I am not quoting from --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did she say that at any time?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did she say that at any time, that she doesn't have anything --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: She did not say it at anytime, using the word “conspiracy,” but I think that when you read the speech as a whole, you can rationally infer that she was alleging a conspiracy between the Government and the Judge in widening the rules of evidence --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose she had made --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose she had made this identical speech at the identical time in the identical place and had not been a lawyer in the case.
Would that make any difference?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Under the Canons of Ethics, I would say she had violated Canon 1, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You would say that any lawyer who had made this speech should be disbarred just -- suspended just as she has been?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, it doesn't depend of the fact that she was counsel of the law.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It aggravates the situation by virtue of the fact that she was counsel in the pending case.
When --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about a law --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: When a lawyer gets up --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about a law review article?
It makes charges tantamount to the same thing.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I'm not prepared to answer a law review article that makes the same charges.
If the writer of the law review article imputes a dishonest motive to the Judge but the Judge is scrapping all rules of evidence, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's done --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- that he is allowing --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's done pretty often, isn't it?
I think I have seen some editorial of Judge Richmond to that effect.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, there's no doubt about it.
There's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How about the opinion of this Court?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I think that this Court is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose that many is the same that you said, here, you'd find the -- an opinion from this Court.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes.
I think that this Court is subject to criticism.

Frankly, I have criticized some of the decisions of this Court, but I'm not here litigating today and last night, I wasn't out making a speech criticizing this Court for the shocking and horrible things that go on in here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you think, if you hadn't gone out and made a speech somewhere here criticizing the Court for what it's doing, that you could have been disbarred in whole or in part?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I think, frankly, that I would be subject to censure if I showed disrespect to this Court and that's all we're claiming, that she was disrespectful to the Court under Canon 1.
I mean, what do you have to do to be disrespectful to a court?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's one of the problems through history as to what was disrespectful to the Court and to whether that was enough to take away a person's liberty or his right to do something.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, she's merely being deprived temporarily.
If the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's a --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: If the Canons of Ethics are going to be nullified, in effect, by allowing people to go out during the course of a trial and accuse a presiding Trial Judge of getting together, so to speak, with the prosecution so that the prosecution can allow or put in all kinds of testimony, then, I think that the Canons of Ethics are worthless.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have they been adopted as a part of the Law of Hawaii?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Canons of Ethics have been adopted by the Supreme Court of the Territory of Hawaii.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there been any statute adopting it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There's no statute.
It's merely by rule of the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do all the decisions of your Court rest on statute?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not necessarily, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do -- are there any times when people's rights to make a living are taken away from them without a law passed to that effect?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not that I know of, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In Hawaii or anywhere else?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not that I know, sir.
No one is taking away anybody's living here, sir.
They're suspending --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I should --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- your license for one year.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I should think that that would be a play on words.

A person whose practice, goes to law school, I don't know how long, takes all the courses and gets ready, to say that you deprive them of the right to practice for a year does not affect their right to have the ability to earn a living.
Your case may be alright on the other grounds, but I don't believe that would support that argument.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, there's no doubt in my mind that if we're being practical, if she is suspended for a year, she losses whatever earning capacity she has for that year.
I don't deny or dispute that but there's big -- one bigger question here, may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Just one?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, there's one in answer to this question and that is whether a lawyer is engaged in a business, or whether we're engaged in a profession, and whether we, as lawyers, are bound by standards that are a little higher than a businessman.
The petitioner makes the statement in this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- reply --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think, whichever it is, that a lawyer is entitled to any less protection than an ordinary citizen?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, I think lawyers are entitled to as much, if not more, protection than ordinary citizens.
But I certainly think that a lawyer's conduct should be guided by a higher formula, a higher degree, or a higher standard than an ordinary citizen.

And if a lawyer is not supposed to be guided by a different standard than an ordinary businessman, then I say that the Supreme Court should say, in effect, that “insofar as the Canons of Ethics are concerned, disregard them.”

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you going to leave yourself time to discuss the juror question?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I think so, sir.
I think that I've covered the speech incident sufficiently.
I think if the Court will look at our brief, we have tried to itemize and corroborate each one of the statements that was made by Matsuoka in his notes.
And before I get off that subject, I would just like to say to the Court that it isn't only Matsuoka's notes that is part of this record.
If the Court will look at the record, the Court will find out that Matsuoka was put under oath and he testified for 17 pages, and petitioner's counsel cross-examined him extensively and intensely.
And Matsuoka testified under oath to many of the statements that are found in his notes and in a newspaper article.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just before you leave that point for good, is -- am I right in understanding that it's your basic position that the First Amendment does not protect a lawyer from being disciplined for unethical conduct even thought that conduct may consist in -- simply in speech which is, we may assume, protected speech from the point of view of the -- that the citizen might make from the First Amendment but still, that that does not protect a lawyer from disciplinary proceedings taken to discipline him in his professional status.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.
If it does, then Canon 1 is worthless.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, most the Canons or many of them are worthless, aren't they?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If -- if that -- if --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, that's what I -- that's why I say that if you hold that a lawyer is to be measured by the clear and present danger test that Judge Pope advocates, then you might just as well scrap the Canons of Ethics.

And frankly, I have been operating under the Canons of Ethics for a long time and if the Supreme Court feels that they are worthy of being scrapped, I would like to be so advised because I'd like to get in there and meet my competition.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do we have to pass on all those other Canons of Ethics in order to decide whether a lawyer could be disbarred for making a speech?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why do you say that this necessarily scrapped the Canons of Ethics?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, if you're scrapping the First Canon of Ethics, I think that you're scrapping one of the most important of all the Canons of Ethics which requires a lawyer to show a little respect for the court in which he is advocating.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What about the jury or the juror's point?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It's our contention that petitioner violated Canon 23, Opinion 109 of the American Bar Association, violated the Rakes and Millie rulings.
After the verdict, Mrs. Bouslog got a telephone call on a Friday night from a woman who was the sister of the sick juror.
This woman was a member of the ILWU.
She called Mrs. Bouslog and said, “My brother is sick.”
Mrs. Bouslog said, “Is he a member of the ILWU?”
Or something to that effect.
She is -- she indicated he was.
So, she says, “I'll be right down.”
She went down and she found the juror to be in a very weakened position.
I think her affidavit indicates that he was motionless, that he certainly was too sick to be talked to at that time.
She talked to the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Have you given us all of the conversation that took place between the two at the --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, I have not, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- at the beginning?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I am --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, why don't you give us the sum of the rest of it?
That might be important.
All you told us was that she said, “My brother is sick,” and the respondent or the applicant here said, “Well, is he a member of the ILWU?”
Now, those things, in themselves, don't mean very much.
Were they acquainted?
Do they know each other, these people who --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, I was coming to that sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Mrs. Bouslog is the attorney for the ILWU.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I know.
I know, but I'm just wondering if you told us what the fair import of this first conversation was where the woman called.
Is that all that was said?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I am practically quoting the record verbatim, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's all that was said, that's all?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Mrs. Cabreros who is the sister of the juror, Fuller, called Mrs. Bouslog who is the attorney for the ILWU.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: And she said to Mrs. Bouslog, “My brother David, who was the juror, is sick.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: And Mrs. --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did she say anything else that he'd said?
Did she say that he -- she --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Mrs. Cabreros?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did she say he wanted to see her?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: She indicated in her conversation that he wanted to see her.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: For this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: And she indicated that she had told Mrs. Bouslog that her brother was yelling, “Frame up!”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was what?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Was yelling “frame up!”
F-R-A-M-E -U-P, frame up.
And because of the fact that he was yelling “frame up,” the fact that he was sick, she went --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you mean by that?
Did she use the word “yelling?”

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why did she say that her brother said that the conviction was a frame up?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Words to that effect.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's a rather important part of this conversation that you only told us fragmentarily, isn't it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It is sir, I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why didn't --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: If the Court wants me --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why didn't you tell us that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- to, I can read the record for the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, no, but if you're going to relate the conversation, I would suggest that you relate the important parts of it so that -- so that we can understand what the genesis of this whole thing was.
Well, don't bother about that now.
I'll give you three minutes to -- to state your position on this because your time has expired.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Alright, sir.
The -- anyway, Mrs. Cabreros indicated to Mrs. Bouslog that her brother wanted to see her.
Mrs. Bouslog came down, she found the brother sick in bed.
She did not interview the juror on that occasion.
She came back the following day and conducted a very searching examination, an inquiry of the juror as to what transpired in the jury room.

And I think that our brief shows that the juror, presumably, related 30 different incidents that occurred in the jury room and she submitted that affidavit to Judge Wiig in an attempt to impeach the verdict.
The judge, as I recall the situation, did not have a hearing on that affidavit, but the Bar Association charged her with this violation of conducting a studied interrogation of the Juror Fuller.

And the evidence before the Court in the record will indicate that Mrs. Fuller had made many of the statements to Mrs. Bouslog, that Mrs. Bouslog did not advise Judge Wiig of the exact physical condition or mental condition of the juror, that she related to Judge Wiig the conversation that she allegedly had with the juror, and the many things that the juror told her occurred in the jury room.
And the -- Mrs. Bouslog did not tell the judge in her affidavit that the Juror Fuller was too sick to sign an affidavit.

She did not tell the judge that she tried to get the wife, Mrs. Fuller, to sign an affidavit but Mrs. Fuller said, “I won't sign that affidavit because what you have in that affidavit is not what my husband said.”
So, Mrs. Bouslog decided to sign the affidavit instead.
And the Court has before it the record of the doctor that treated the juror.
The Court has before it the record of the psychiatrist that treated the juror.
And we feel that under all the circumstances, that studied interrogation violated Canon 23 and it violated the holdings in the Millie and Rakes cases.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was it -- was it misconduct for her to go out and see this juror?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It depended on what she went out to seem him for.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, in response to this telephone message that her client had been framed, was it misconduct for her to investigate that after her juror had been discharged from duty?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Canon 3 says -- or 23 says that a lawyer should never communicate with a juror, that's before or after and during the course of a trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, there would be thousands of lawyers disbarred in this country if that rule was observed.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, it's possibly so and if the Court feels that you can interrogate a juror after verdict, why, I'm sure that there are lots of us lawyers who adhere to the Canons and don't interrogate jurors.
We would like to know because we'd like to get to the jurors too --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there any law --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- to find out what they're thinking about.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there any law against it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Any law against it in Hawaii?
Is there any statute against it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There is no statute against interrogating a juror, sir, except that the Ninth Circuit Court has laid down a rule in the Millie case which indicates that it is a violation of the Canons of Ethics to interrogate jurors, to -- to conduct a studied interrogation of jurors after verdict.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, you mean if the -- if the lawyer hears that there's been misconduct that brought about the conviction of his client, that he violates some kind of law written by the Courts so somebody else to make inquiry about it, of the juror?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well it's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that what this second charge is based on, this second -- the part of the --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The second charge is based on a fact that she conducted a studied interrogation of a juror.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you mean by “studied?”

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The witness Hall indicates that we would develop the subject.
We would ask him questions, he would answer.
She would ask a question, I would ask a question, and he would answer.
We would develop a subject then go onto another subject.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They had a right to do it.
They had a right to do it their way, didn't they?
I don't quite get what you mean by that.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, the Ninth Circuit Court, may it please Justice Black, has decided in the Millie case that it's unethical and it's not proper for a lawyer to conduct a studied investigation or interrogation of a juror after a trial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do they use the word “studied” and make that a part of it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I'm not sure that I am quoting the exact words but that's the import of the ruling and holding of the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, then, under that rule, as you understand it, even if a person's file had been convicted of a crime, and he's learns that one of the jurors says there has been some misconduct that they ought to know about, that he would be subject to disbarment if he went down to the juror and made inquiries on it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Under certain circumstances, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I'm talking about the circumstance that he learns or he's told that this juror says that there's been misconduct if -- that he should know about in connection with the conviction of his client.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: He is not supposed to conduct an investigation of a juror subsequent to a verdict.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He could go to the judge but need not tell him about it.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, I mean --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Could he do that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- that's too simple for some --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- lawyers to do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I said that's too simple --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- for some lawyers to do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean, there's nothing in the law or in the understanding of the Bar or in the conceptions of propriety that prevents him from going to the judge, is there?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not to my knowledge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But where is anything --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Judge is available for that purpose.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is anything in any law in any state in this Union that bar, it may be there, I don't know, I never heard of it, --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that bars a lawyer from investigating and asking a juror after the case is decided in connection with an effort to find out if there's been something done wrong?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, it's -- we have it in our brief, sir, in the Millie case and in the Rakes case.
One is the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals and the other is the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that based on a statute?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What you are --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- saying is if there is a general understanding with the Bar that lawyers don't have relations with jurors during, before -- or after or during the trial, isn't that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And what do you base the statement on that there is such a general understanding after the jury has been discharged, anything but those two cases?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Those two cases, plus, Canon 23.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Which is really before us.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And did those cases -- in those cases, did the juror ask to see the lawyer?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, I think, may it please the Court, I think that if you read the evidence, you'll find out how and who asked to see what lawyer in this particular case.
It isn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I haven't done that.

Could you please tell us what bearing what you said a little while ago that the lawyer asked -- this lawyer asked the wife to sign an affidavit prepared by her which the wife refused to sign because she said it didn't contain what her husband said.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, is that in the evidence?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was that before the Committee of the Bar and the Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That it ended to the conclusion on this point?
Was that relevant to this -- to the charge?
Was it relevant to the charge --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that a lawyer prepared an affidavit containing things which did not represent what the witness, quoted in the affidavit, supposedly said and asked somebody to sign it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It was relevant to the charge in this respect, that when they asked us for a bill of particulars as to whether the affidavit was true or false, we stated that we did not make any statement as to the truth or falsity of the affidavit.
All we say is that the affidavit, its contents, and the manner in which it was secured violate the Canons of Ethics.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I want to know is whether the Supreme Court of Hawaii had before it testimony that an affidavit is prepared which included matter that did not correspond to the author who was quoted as having said what was in the affidavit, and whether the Hawaii Supreme Court deemed that relevant to the charge before it.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: They had before it that -- those facts and they deemed it very relevant to the findings in this case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, what I'd like to know, as this has come out at the last moment, is for you to point out in the record where that is the basis on which the suspension rests, in one sentence in the whole record.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I can't point out --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can you --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- that that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can you point it out later and send it to us where it would show where that was the basis on which this second charge was sustained?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, by, that I don't understand what Justice Black that if --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I know that there's some kind of --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- when you say “that,” --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- some kind of judgments --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- what do you mean by “that?”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Some kind of judgment and some kind of order.
If a person has been found guilty of perpetrating a false affidavit, I assume that you wouldn't want that done by implication.
Where did the Court find that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The Court made no finding that there was a false affidavit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where did the --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- where did the Bar Association?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: They made no finding on that sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where did they charge it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: They didn't charge her on that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They didn't charge it.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: And I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They didn't charge it and they didn't find it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right and I did not so --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You want us to look at the record to find out if they could have done something on that if they had charged it and the Court had found it.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I did not make any statement to Justice Frankfurter that the affidavit contained a false one.
I say that the Court can easily, after it reads the evidence and evaluates the evidence, come to the conclusion that perhaps, the affidavit didn't state facts.
And my answer to Justice Frankfurter was that Mrs. Fuller stated to Mrs. Bouslog that “I will not sign this affidavit because this affidavit does not contain the facts as they are.”

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: My --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And the question I asked was did the Bar Association charge that.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: We did not charge her with --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Alright, the Bar Association didn't charge it.
Did the Bar Association find that to be a fact?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is that finding?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There's a finding by the Bar Committee to that effect.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Rather than take the time of the Court, I would like permission to -- “with respect to the charges in paragraph 3, the Committee finds that when” --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where are you reading from?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Page 15 of the record, sir.

“With respect to the charges in paragraph 3, the Committee finds that after rendition of the verdict in Criminal 10 Corps 95 mentioned above Mrs. Bouslog visited one of the jurors, David P. Fuller, Jr. while he was in a very poor mental and physical condition, and thereafter, submitted her affidavit concerning an interview with the juror to the presiding Judge.

While the affidavit of Mrs. Bouslog indicates that on the first occasion, he was gravely ill, the Committee finds that she did not fully disclose to the Court the condition of Mr. Fuller, nor the fact that she had attempted to get affidavits from Mrs. Fuller who refused to sign one and could not get an affidavit from Mr. Fuller because of his condition.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does that say it's false?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, it doesn't say it's false.
I didn't say it was false either.
I said that the testimony of Mrs. Fuller indicated that Mrs. Fuller made the statement that the matters contained in the affidavit weren't factual.
That's all I said.
And I say to this Court that you can very easily come to the conclusion that that is a false affidavit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Since I got you into this, I think I will just state what my question was.

My question was whether there is in the record evidence that an affidavit prepared by the lawyer purporting to set forth the facts was submitted to a witness, to a person to sign, Mrs. Fuller, who refused to sign because she said it didn't conform to what she understood her husband had said.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Your answer to that was yes.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: It is in the record, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And then -- then, Mrs. Bouslog or Mrs. Sawyer made the affidavit herself.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, she signed --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- the affidavit herself.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, do you -- do you contend that that is a false affidavit?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Is the Court asking me for my personal opinion?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I'm asking you -- of course in accord with this record.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there anything in the record here to indicate that -- that it is false?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: I think that the Court can come to the conclusion that it is a false affidavit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did anybody below come to that conclusion?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The point was never decided by any court below, no, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that doesn't wipe out the fact that she did prepare an affidavit for signature by the wife of the man who's supposed to have said what she made him say and the wife refused to sign it because she said that isn't what her husband said.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is still in the record?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And then sign it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did she sign it then after that?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: When Mrs. Fuller refused to sign the affidavit, then Mrs. Bouslog made an affidavit.
Now, whether it was the same affidavit, the same --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But Mrs. Fuller never signed the affidavit.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, she never did.
She never signed the affidavit because she said, under oath, that it contained matters that were not factual.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think that's the basis on which this woman has been suspended from the Bar, that -- that statement by Mrs. -- the juror's wife?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: You mean if you take it alone, isolate it?
No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm just saying is that's the basis on which this due process that you say has been given her was given to her, that they were suspending her from the Bar because she has a woman to sign an affidavit which the woman said is not the correct?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Sir, that's only part of this whole problem.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's one facet.

That is not the reason why the Court voted suspension, and I might say to the Court that insofar as the Supreme Court of the Territory of Hawaii was concerned, they did not impose any punishment on the second count because they felt that their one-year suspension on the first count was adequate, so that she was not given any suspension for the second count.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do we have it up here at all, the second count?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, frankly, as far as I am concerned, I subscribe very heartily to Justice Lennon's opinion and decision and I don't think that this case should be here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Didn't the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit unanimously believe or a majority of them at least believe that if the second count alone had been involved, that Court would have had no jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The facts we knew were all been called.
This was imposed.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: As a --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It didn't enter into the discipline, did it?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: As a matter of fact, the Court decided that she was guilty on two counts.
It isn't very artfully set out by the Supreme Court and as a matter of fact, the petitioner herself did not bring the matter up on appeal in the Ninth Circuit Court.
They took it upon themselves to look into the matter and write the opinion that they did.
The only thing that the petitioner went up to the Ninth Circuit on was the first count involving the speech.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Yes, sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Only when she --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: She didn't ever sign on anything.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.
The Court said that “we feel that the year's suspension is sufficient and we will not impose an additional punishment on the second count,” sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask a jurisdictional question about this.
I'm fully ignorant.

As I understand from the cases that have come here, the two cases, we have said over the last 20 years that there are certain limitations upon the reviewing power of the Ninth Circuit of judgments in the Supreme Court of Hawaii.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, assume, as you indicate, assume that the second -- the proceeding -- the disciplinary proceeding had related solely to the second count.
You just indicated that Judge Lemmon held that that was not a given basis for review, is that right?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: No, I indicated that Justice Lemmon, at the very first hearing, indicated that the Ninth Circuit did not have jurisdiction over this matter for two reasons.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, the whole case -- the whole case --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: For two reasons.
First of all, he said that there was no constitutional question involved.
Secondly, --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The monetary amount?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: The monetary amount that the license to practice --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there a difference --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: -- had no price tag.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In your view, is there a difference between the subject matter of the two charges so far as the jurisdiction of the Ninth Circuit was concerned?
Suppose the second charge stood alone.
Would that be reviewable on the basis on which they reviewed this case?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Well, she got no punishment for the second charge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: If she got a punishment for the second charge, I would say that is was not reviewable for the very simple reason that I don't think that the right to practice law carries with it a price tag.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well that's -- that's the question that we have in other relations, namely, whether the monetary requirement giving jurisdiction is satisfied, which we struggled with that.
The Court has struggled with it for 50 years.
This is another case, but that would be equally true as to the second count -- or, rather, the first count if he had been given the sentence of it, is that right?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And so, we have a case here where there were finding of -- there was a -- there was a finding against the defendant below on both counts but sentence was imposed only on one count.

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, there is no sentence here on the count subject to review, is that right?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: Not the sentence, no, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No sentence here, nothing -- nothing --

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: There's nothing before the Court on that because there's no sentence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There's no sentence, but there was a determination of the issue, is that right?

turn.speaker: a_william_barlow
turn.label: Mr. A. William Barlow
turn.text: That's right.
She was found guilty of gross misconduct on the two charges.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. McTernan.

turn.speaker: john_t_mcternan
turn.label: Mr. John T. McTernan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Although I did not have time yesterday to get to the jury point, I would like not to get to it today but to speak to the speech point because I think that's the more important aspect of the case.

Mr. Justice Harlan, if I might reformulate the question you put to my adversary, I would say that the holding below was that it is unprofessional conduct for a lawyer of record in a pending case to comment upon that case in the manner petitioner did here because, and this is the guts of it, I think, that is an attack on the administration of justice.
And I think that is the question begging aspect of the findings of the courts below.
What is meant by “attack?”

“Attack” obviously embraces criticism and fair comment, and a lawyer's utterances have to go beyond, it seems to me, criticism and fair conduct even of the conduct of the judge himself before he brings the Court into disrespect, before he interferes with a fair administration of justice, before he loses his First Amendment protection.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Didn't you say, as certainly I understood you, on the trial in the District Court, you're not supposed to talk about the cases, in public, being tried in the courts?

turn.speaker: john_t_mcternan
turn.label: Mr. John T. McTernan
turn.text: I think that this is a convention which most lawyers observe.
It's one that I observe in my practice.

I do this and I think lawyers do it because they are solicitous to avoid even the appearance of interfering with the fair administration of justice, but I don't think that it is something that is compulsory upon lawyers just because they are in that situation because what they say may well not interfere with the unfair administration of justice or bring the Court into disrespect as a matter of fact.
And I think this is what we're concerned with here.
